text:
From James Strachan web log (which I completely agree with)

From time to time on some project or via some tool or framework I use log4j
directly or indirectly through some other library. I started using log4j way
back when it was at IBM. For the most part its a reasonable piece of software
that does what it says on the tin.

However I've lost count of the times I've swore loudly at log4j for, you guessed
it, giving this lovely output...

log4j:WARN No appenders could be found for logger (foo).
log4j:WARN Please initialize the log4j system properly.

And then refusing to let you see any output whatsoever of the tool / project
you've just run. How useful!

Then you spend an hour or two messing around with whatever tool / build /
project / framework to munge some log4j.properties on the classpath / in a
system property just to see some damned logging output.

Why oh why couldn't log4j just do the useful thing of logging a warning that its
not found a configuration, but then go right ahead and use a sensible default,
logging INFO & WARN level output to the console. If nothing else it'd reduce the
amount of swearing :)
creator: jerome@coffeebreaks.org
eross@m-qube.com
text:
Ceki Gulcu wrote
> 1) On certain systems there is no such thing as a default output device, e.g. a 
> console. 2) More importantly, if the user has not configured log4j, chances are 
> that no one is actually interested in the log output. If the user is interested 
> in the log output, is it an unreasonable requirement to ask her to configure
> log4j?

0) The user is lazy.  java.util.logging ships with a JVM default.
http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.4.2/docs/guide/util/logging/overview.html [1.9]
1) Even if there is no console, STDOUT usually goes someplace useful.
2) You already output a few lines to the console saying configure it properly. 
This sort of contradicts your philosophy about log4j working with non-console
maachines.  It also serves to piss people off.

If I'm some person using *somebody else's software* that relies on log4j (which
isn't configured correctly) I might have no idea how to get things working.  I
might have no idea when I see that message what to do.

> 2) You already output a few lines to the console saying configure it properly. 
> This sort of contradicts your philosophy about log4j working with non-console
> maachines.  It also serves to piss people off.

Good point.
creator: ceki@apache.org

text:
As of version 1.3, log4j is self-reliant for its own logging. In
particular, within the configuration phase, log4j may generate log
messages. These are replayed after log4j is fully configured. The fact
that log4j does not rely on a default configuration makes such
reentrant behavior tractable. Note that as of version 1.3, log4j no
longer emits the dreaded messages.

 log4j:WARN No appenders could be found for logger (foo).
 log4j:WARN Please initialize the log4j system properly.

Moreover, components using ULoggers (UGLI interface) may swap
ugli-simple.jar instead of log4j.jar. This will engage a default
behavior very similar to what you describe. 

For more details on UGLI please see

  http://logging.apache.org/log4j/ugli.html
creator: ceki@apache.org
